questions.text: A patient presents with loss of sensation on the posterior surface of the ear along with a lesion. Which structure is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The Greater Auricular Nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (C2-C3) and provides sensory innervation to:

  • The posterior surface of the ear.
  • The skin over the angle of the mandible and parotid gland.
  • Part of the posterior auricular region.

Lesions affecting this nerve can lead to loss of sensation in these areas.

 

Other options:

 

Internal Jugular Vein (Option B): A major venous structure that drains blood from the head and neck but does not contribute to sensory innervation.

 

External Jugular Vein (Option C): Also a venous structure, responsible for draining superficial areas of the head, but not involved in sensation.


External Carotid Artery (Option D): A major arterial supply to the face and scalp, but it does not play a role in sensory innervation.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of recurrent lesions on lips as shown below, which is associated with fever. Which of the following is the characteristic feature seen in Tzanck smear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Multinucleated giant cells

Explanation:

  • The image given in the question is of Herpes labialis which is caused by Herpes simplex virus.
  • Fever is one of the predisposing factor of Herpes labialis
  • It is also called cold sore.
  • It is usually present on the vermillion border of the lips.
  • Smear is taken from the base of the vesicle
  • Multinucleated giant cells and Acantholytic cells are present on Tzanck smear

Herpes labialis/cold sore:

  • Reactivation of latent infection in trigeminal ganglion, causing asymptomatic shedding or clinically evident recurrent disease.
  • Causative organism: HSV-1 > HSV-2.
  • Features:
  • Painful and pruritic lesions.
  • Fever is often present, which subsides in 3-5 days. The initial vesicular lesions become pustular and then crusted before healing in 7-10 days without scarring.
  • Can be associated with itching or burning before the development of lesions.
  • Recurrent herpetic lesions are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.
  • Treatment:

First line
  • Acyclovir (topical/oral)
  • Hydrocolloid dressing
  • Topical penciclovir

Second line
  • Long-term prophylactic acyclovir

Third line
  • IV acyclovir
  • Penciclovir
  • Foscarnet
  • IV cidofovir
  • Topical imiquimod

Handerson patterson bodies (Option A): Handerson patterson bodies is a histologic finding seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

Owl eye appearance (Option C): refers to basophilic intranuclear inclusions surrounded by a clear halo, characteristic of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

Acanthosis (Option D): Acanthosis is a histopathological finding seen in Chronic eczema.

questions.text: A man presents with a rash on his flank, with Itching for the past 2 weeks. The patient has tried several over-the-counter medications without any improvement. In physical examination, the rash is seen on his palms and the sole of one foot, but no oral lesions are found. What is the Iikely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Erythema multiforme

Explanation:

Erythema multiforme is usually seen as a reaction to drugs or HSV. It presents as target lesions on the palms, soles, or trunk. It shows a dusky, central area or blister, a dark red inflammatory zone surrounded by a pale ring of edema, and an erythematous halo on the extreme periphery of the lesion.

Urticaria (Option A): It usually presents as wheals  (erythematous, edematous, itchy, and evanescent lesions). They are small and multiple as shown below:

Viral exanthem (Option B): Exanthems usually start in the trunk and spread to other parts

Tinea manuum (Option D): Skin lesions caused by dermatophytes in the palms. It is a circular ring-shaped scaly lesion.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a generalized vesicular rash covering the entire body. The child's parents report that the rash started as red spots and quickly developed into fluid-filled blisters. The child also has a mild fever and is feeling irritable. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Varicella

  • This is the most likely diagnosis based on the symptoms described. Varicella is a viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). It typically presents with a generalized vesicular rash that starts as red spots and quickly develops into fluid-filled blisters. The child may also have a mild fever and feel irritable. Chickenpox is common in children and is highly contagious. The vesicles eventually crust over and heal. It's important to note that a vaccine is available for varicella, which has greatly reduced the incidence of the disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Shingles (Herpes Zoster): Shingles is also caused by the varicella-zoster virus. However, it typically occurs in adults who had chickenpox earlier in life. Shingles presents as a painful, localized vesicular rash along a specific dermatome (nerve pathway). It is less likely in a 3-year-old child and would present differently than the generalized rash described in the scenario.

Option C - Smallpox: Smallpox is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the variola virus. However, smallpox has been eradicated from the general population due to successful vaccination efforts, and it hasn't been reported since the late 1970s. The symptoms and presentation of smallpox are different from the scenario described.

Option D - Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease that affects the muscles and skin. It typically presents with muscle weakness and a characteristic skin rash, but the rash pattern and symptoms are distinct from the generalized vesicular rash described in the scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following does not exhibit the Koebner's phenomenon?
questions.solution:
• The development of skin lesions in areas of trauma or injury is referred to as Koebner's phenomenon, also known as the isomorphic response. It is a typical finding in a few skin conditions, including psoriasis, lichen planus, vitiligo, and morphea.
  • Koebner's peculiarity isn't found in all skin conditions, nonetheless, and one condition in which it is commonly not noticed is rosacea.

Incorrect choices:

  • Option a. Vitiligo: Vitiligo is an immune system sickness. When the immune system attacks melanocyte-containing cells in the body it results in vitiligo. These are pigment-making cells.
  • Option b. Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a skin condition that typically manifests as a rash with itchy, scaly patches on the scalp, trunk, knees, and elbows. Psoriasis is a prevalent, chronic, and long-term condition that has no cure. 
  • Option c. Lichen planus: Lichen planus is a condition of the skin, hair, nails, mouth, and genitals. On the skin, lichen planus often appears as purple, itchy, flat bumps that develop over several weeks.

questions.text: A female presents with multiple small, pink, umbilicated papules on the face. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Molluscum contagiosum

Explanation:

The description of the skin lesions—multiple small, pink, umbilicated papules—is the classic clinical presentation of Molluscum contagiosum.

  • Etiology: This is a common, self-limiting viral skin infection caused by a poxvirus.
  • Lesion Characteristics: The lesions are typically flesh-colored or pink, dome-shaped papules with a characteristic central umbilication (a small indentation or dimple in the center).
  • Affected Population: It is most common in children, particularly on the face, trunk, and extremities, but can also be seen in sexually active adults in the genital area.

Incorrect Options:

Herpes simplex (Option B) presents as grouped vesicles (small blisters) on an erythematous base, not umbilicated papules.

Human papillomavirus (HPV) (Option C) causes warts, which are typically warty, hyperkeratotic papules and nodules, and they do not have the central umbilication seen in molluscum.

Hyperkeratotic Growth

Acne vulgaris (Option D) is characterized by comedones (blackheads and whiteheads), papules, pustules, and cysts. The lesions are not typically umbilicated.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the characteristic lesion of Kaposi sarcoma?

choices.text: A white, striated lesion that cannot be scraped off

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A raised, purple-red lesion:

Explanation:

The characteristic lesion of Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a raised, purple-red lesion.

  • Etiology: Kaposi sarcoma is a type of cancer caused by the Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).
  • Lesion Morphology: The lesions typically begin as flat, reddish-purple macules and progress into raised, palpable plaques and nodules. The color is a result of extravasated red blood cells and hemosiderin deposition. The violaceous (purple-red) appearance is a hallmark of this condition.
  • Affected Population: It is most commonly seen in patients with compromised immune systems, particularly those with HIV/AIDS.

Incorrect Options:

A yellow lesion containing pus (Option A) would suggest a bacterial infection, like a carbuncle or abscess.

A white, striated lesion that cannot be scraped off (Option B) is a classic description of oral hairy leukoplakia or lichen planus, not Kaposi sarcoma.

Small, red erosions (Option D) are a non-specific finding that can be seen in many different skin conditions, such as dermatitis or candidiasis, and do not specifically describe Kaposi sarcoma.

questions.text: A child was brought with c/o multiple lesions. O/E multiple vesicular lesions are seen on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent causing the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Coxsackie virus

Explanation:

The most likely etiological agent causing multiple vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa in a child is Coxsackie virus.

  • The classic presentation described—vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and oral mucosa—is characteristic of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD).
  • HFMD is most commonly caused by Coxsackievirus A16 and occasionally other coxsackievirus strains (like A6, A10) and Enterovirus 71. However, Coxsackievirus remains the prototypical agent linked to these clinical findings in children.

Incorrect Options:

Varicella-zoster virus (Option A) Causes chickenpox, which presents with a generalized vesicular rash, mostly on the trunk and face.

Human herpesvirus 6 (Option B) Most known for roseola, characterized by a sudden fever followed by a maculopapular rash, not vesicular and not localized to palms/soles/oral mucosa.

Enterovirus (Option C) While technically correct as a viral genus that includes both Coxsackievirus and Enterovirus 71, the most specific and most commonly implicated answer is "Coxsackie virus."
